standard_metadata.standard_description: Understand a fraction a/b as a multiple of 1/b.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Equivalent whole number and fraction multiplication expressions

question.content: Priya is making a table with expressions that are equal to $6\times\dfrac25$.  **Help Priya complete the table.**   | | :- | :- | $6\times\dfrac25$ | $= $ | $12\times\dfrac15$   $6\times\dfrac25$| $ = $ | $4\times\dfrac35$     $6\times\dfrac25$ | $=$ | $2\times{}$

hints.content: Priya was able to find several equivalent expressions to $6\times\dfrac25$.   Let's see how she did it!

##Why does $6\times\dfrac{2}{5}= 12 \times \dfrac{1}{5}$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 6\times\blueD{\dfrac25}\\\\ &= 6 \times \left({\blueD2\times \blueD{\dfrac{1}{5}}}\right)\\\\ &= (6 \times\blueD2) {\times \blueD{\dfrac{1}{5}}}\\\\ &= 12 \times \dfrac{1}{5} \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $6\times\dfrac{2}{5}$ and $12 \times \dfrac{1}{5}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fractions bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 6 equal parts, each labeled two-fifths. The bottom bar is divided into 12 equal parts, each part labeled one-fifth.  Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-fifths to twelve-fifths with tick marks at every one-fifth unit. Above the number line, there are labels every two-fifths unit. There is a dot at twelve-fifths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##Why does $6\times\dfrac{2}{5}= 4 \times \dfrac{3}{5}$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 6\times{\dfrac25}\\\\ &= \maroonD{12} \times \dfrac{1}{5}\\\\ &=(\maroonD4\times\maroonD3) \times \dfrac15\\\\ &=\maroonD4 \times \left( \maroonD3\times\dfrac15 \right)\\\\ &=\maroonD4 \times \dfrac{\maroonD3}5 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:    [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $6\times\dfrac{2}{5}$ and $4 \times \dfrac{3}{5}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fractions bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 6 equal parts, each labeled two-fifths. The bottom bar is divided into 4 equal parts, each part labeled three-fifths.  Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-fifths to twelve-fifths with tick marks at every one-fifth unit and labels every three-fifths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every two-fifths unit. There is a dot at twelve-fifths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##What completes $6\times\dfrac{2}{5}= 2 \times \square$ ?  Now, we need to find the missing information for the equivalent expression $2\times\square{}$.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \purpleE6\times{\dfrac25}\\\\ &=(\purpleE2\times\purpleE3) \times {\dfrac{2}{5}}\\\\ &=\purpleE2 \times \left(\purpleE3\times{\dfrac{2}{5}}\right)\\\\ &= 2 \times \dfrac{6}{5} \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:  [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $6\times\dfrac{2}{5}$ and $2 \times \dfrac{6}{5}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fractions bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 6 equal parts, each labeled two-fifths. The bottom bar is divided into 2 equal parts, each part labeled six-fifths.  Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-fifths to twelve-fifths with tick marks at every one-fifth unit and labels every six-fifths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every two-fifths unit. There is a dot at twelve-fifths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: Here is the complete table:   | | :- | :- | $6\times\dfrac25$ | $= $ | $12\times\dfrac15$   $6\times\dfrac25$| $ = $ | $4\times\dfrac35$     $6\times\dfrac25$ | $=$ | $2\times\purpleE{\dfrac65}$

question.content: Nancy is making a table with expressions that are equal to $8\times\dfrac34$.  **Help Nancy complete the table.**   | | :- | :- | $8\times\dfrac34$ | $= $ | $24\times{}$  $8\times\dfrac34$| $ = $ | $4\times\dfrac64$     $8\times\dfrac34$ | $=$ | $6\times\dfrac44$

hints.content: Nancy was able to find several equivalent expressions to $8\times\dfrac34$.   Let's see how she did it!

##Why does $8\times\dfrac{3}{4}= 4 \times \dfrac{6}{4}$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD8\times{\dfrac34}\\\\ &=(\blueD4\times\blueD2)\times\dfrac34\\\\ &=\blueD4\times \left(\blueD2\times\dfrac34 \right)\\\\ &= \blueD4 \times \dfrac{\blueD6}{4} \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $8\times\dfrac{3}{4}$ and $4 \times \dfrac{6}{4}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 8 equal parts with each part labeled three-fourths. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 4 equal parts with each part labeled six-fourths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-fourths to twenty-four fourths with tick marks at every one-fourth unit and labels every six-fourths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every three-fourths unit. There is a dot at twenty-four fourths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##Why does $8\times\dfrac{3}{4}= 6\times\dfrac44$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \maroonD8\times{\dfrac34}\\\\ &=( \maroonD{4\times2})\times\dfrac34\\\\ &=(\maroonD2\times3)\times \dfrac{\maroonD4}4\\\\ &=6\times\dfrac{4}{4} \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:  [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $8\times\dfrac{3}{4}$ and $ 6\times\dfrac44$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 8 equal parts with each part labeled three-fourths. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 6 equal parts with each part labeled four-fourths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-fourths to twenty-four fourths with tick marks at every one-fourth unit and labels every four-fourths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every three-fourths unit. There is a dot at twenty-four fourths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##What completes $8\times\dfrac{3}{4}= 24 \times \square$ ?  Now, we need to find the missing information for the equivalent expression $24\times\square{}$.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 8\times\dfrac3{4}\\\\ &=8\times \left( \dfrac{\redE{3}\times\redE1}{4} \right)\\\\ &=(8\times\redE3)\times\dfrac{\redE1}{4} \\\\ &= {24}\times\redE{\dfrac{1}{4}}  \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:  [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $8\times\dfrac{3}{4}$ and $24 \times \dfrac{1}{4}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 8 equal parts with each part labeled three-fourths. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 24 equal parts with each part labeled one-fourth. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-fourths to twenty-four fourths with tick marks at every one-fourth unit and labels every two-fourths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every three-fourths unit. There is a dot at twenty-four fourths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: Here is the complete table:   | | :- | :- | $8\times\dfrac34$ | $= $ | $24\times\redE{\dfrac14}$ $8\times\dfrac34$| $ = $ | $4\times\dfrac64$     $8\times\dfrac34$ | $=$ | $6\times\dfrac44$

question.content: Logan is making a table with expressions that are equal to $20\times\dfrac15$.  **Help Logan complete the table.**   | | :- | :- | $20\times\dfrac15$ | $= $ | $2\times\dfrac{10}5$ $20\times\dfrac15$| $ = $ | $\dfrac55\times4$    $20\times\dfrac15$ | $=$ |   ${}\times\dfrac25$

hints.content: Logan was able to find several equivalent expressions to $20\times\dfrac15$.   Let's see how he did it!

##Why does $20\times\dfrac15= 2\times\dfrac{10}5$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{20}\times{\dfrac15}\\\\ &=(\blueD2\times\blueD{10})\times\dfrac15\\\\ &=\blueD2\times \left(\blueD{10}\times\dfrac15 \right)\\\\ &= \blueD2 \times \dfrac{\blueD{10}}{5} \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $20\times\dfrac{1}{5}$ and $2 \times \dfrac{10}{5}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 20 equal parts with each part labeled one-fifth. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 2 equal parts with each part labeled ten-fifths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-fifths to twenty-fifths with tick marks at every one-fifth unit and labels every ten-fifths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every one-fifth unit. There is a dot at twenty-fifths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##Why does $20\times\dfrac15=\dfrac55\times4$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \maroonD{20}\times{\dfrac15}\\\\ &= (\maroonD4\times\maroonD5)\times\dfrac15\\\\ &=\maroonD4\times \left( \maroonD5\times\dfrac15 \right)\\\\ &=\maroonD{4}\times\maroonD{\dfrac55}\\\\ &=\maroonD{\dfrac55}\times\maroonD{4} \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:  [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $20\times\dfrac{1}{5}$ and $ \dfrac55\times4$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 20 equal parts with each part labeled one-fifth. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 4 equal parts with each part labeled five-fifths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-fifths to twenty-fifths with tick marks at every one-fifth unit and labels every five-fifths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every one-fifth unit. There is a dot at twenty-fifths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##What completes $20\times\dfrac15= \square\times\dfrac25$ ?  Now, we need to find the missing information for the equivalent expression $\square\times\dfrac25$.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 20\times\dfrac15\\\\ &=(\redE{10}\times\redE2) \times {\dfrac{1}{5}}\\\\ &=\redE{10} \times \left( \redE2 \times{\dfrac{1}{5}} \right)\\\\ &= \redE{10} \times \redE{\dfrac{2}{5}} \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $20\times\dfrac{1}{5}$ and $10\times \dfrac{2}{5}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 20 equal parts with each part labeled one-fifth. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 10 equal parts with each part labeled two-fifths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-fifths to twenty-fifths with tick marks at every one-fifth unit and labels every two-fifths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every one-fifth unit. There is a dot at twenty-fifths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: Here is the complete table:   | | :- | :- | $20\times\dfrac15$ | $= $ | $2\times\dfrac{10}5$ $20\times\dfrac15$| $ = $ | $\dfrac55\times4$    $20\times\dfrac15$ | $=$ | $\redE{10}\times\dfrac25$

question.content: Scott is making a table with expressions that are equal to $\dfrac4{10}\times4$.  **Help Scott complete the table.**   | | :- | :- | $\dfrac4{10}\times4$ | $= $ | $2\times\dfrac{8}{10}$ $\dfrac4{10}\times4$| $ = $ |  $\times\dfrac1{10}$ $\dfrac4{10}\times4$ | $=$ |  $\dfrac2{10}\times8$

hints.content: Scott was able to find several equivalent expressions to $\dfrac4{10}\times4$.   Let's see how he did it!

##Why does $\dfrac4{10}\times4=2\times\dfrac{8}{10}$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\dfrac4{10}\times\blueD4\\\\ &=\dfrac4{10}\times(\blueD2\times\blueD2)\\\\ &=\left(\dfrac4{10}\times\blueD2\right)\times\blueD2\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{8}}{10}\times\blueD2\\\\ &=2\dfrac{8}{10} \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:    [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac{4}{10}\times4$ and $2\dfrac{8}{10}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 4 equal parts with each part labeled four-tenths. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 2 equal parts with each part labeled eight-tenths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-tenths to sixteen-tenths with tick marks at every one-tenth unit and labels every eight-tenths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every four-tenths unit. There is a dot at sixteen-tenths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##Why does $\dfrac4{10}\times4=\dfrac2{10}\times8$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} {\maroonD{\dfrac4{10}}}\times4\\\\ &=\dfrac{\maroonD2\times\maroonD2}{10}\times4\\\\ &=\dfrac2{10}\times(\maroonD2\times4)\\\\ &=\dfrac2{10}\times\maroonD8 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac{4}{10}\times4$ and $ \dfrac2{10}\times8$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 4 equal parts with each part labeled four-tenths. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 8 equal parts with each part labeled two-tenths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-tenths to sixteen-tenths with tick marks at every one-tenth unit and labels every two-tenths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every four-tenths unit. There is a dot at sixteen-tenths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##What completes $\dfrac4{10}\times4= \square\times\dfrac1{10}$ ?  Now, we need to find the missing information for the equivalent expression $\square\times\dfrac1{10}$.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \dfrac4{10}\times4\\\\ &=\left(\dfrac{\goldD{1}\times\goldD4}{10}\right) \times 4\\\\ &=\dfrac{\goldD1}{10} \times (\goldD4\times4)\\\\ &= \dfrac{1}{10} \times \goldD{16} \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac{4}{10}\times4$ and $\dfrac{1}{10}\times16$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 4 equal parts with each part labeled four-tenths. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 16 equal parts with each part labeled one-tenth. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-tenths to sixteen-tenths with tick marks at every one-tenth unit. Above the number line, there are labels every four-tenths unit. There is a dot at sixteen-tenths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: Here is the complete table:   | | :- | :- | $\dfrac4{10}\times4$ | $= $ | $2\times\dfrac{8}{10}$ $\dfrac4{10}\times4$| $ = $ | $\goldD{16}\times\dfrac1{10}$ $\dfrac4{10}\times4$ | $=$ |  $\dfrac2{10}\times8$

question.content: Richard is making a table with expressions that are equal to $\dfrac43\times5$.  **Help Richard complete the table.**   | | :- | :- | $\dfrac43\times5$ | $= $ |  ${}\times\dfrac{1}{3}$ $\dfrac43\times5$ | $ = $ | $10\times\dfrac23$ $\dfrac43\times5$| $=$ |  $\dfrac{10}{3}\times2$

hints.content: Richard was able to find several equivalent expressions to $\dfrac43\times5$.   Let's see how he did it!

##Why does $\dfrac43\times5=10\times\dfrac23$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{\dfrac43}\times5\\\\ &=\left(\dfrac{\blueD2\times\blueD2}{\blueD3} \right) \times5\\\\ &=\dfrac23\times(\blueD2\times5)\\\\ &=\dfrac23\times10\\\\ &=10\times\dfrac23 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac43\times5$ and $10\times\dfrac23$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 5 equal parts with each part labeled four-thirds. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 10 equal parts with each part labeled two-thirds. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-thirds to twenty-thirds with tick marks at every one-third unit and labels every two-thirds unit. Above the number line, there are labels every four-thirds unit. There is a dot at twenty-thirds, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##Why does $\dfrac43\times5=\dfrac{10}{3}\times2$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} {\maroonD{\dfrac4{3}}}\times5\\\\ &=\dfrac{\maroonD2\times\maroonD2}{3}\times5\\\\ &=\maroonD2\times \left(\dfrac{\maroonD2\times5}{3}\right)\\\\ &=2\times\dfrac{10}3\\\\ &=\dfrac{10}{3}\times2 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac43\times5$ and $\dfrac{10}{3}\times2$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 5 equal parts with each part labeled four-thirds. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 2 equal parts with each part labeled ten-thirds. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-thirds to twenty-thirds with tick marks at every one-third unit and labels every ten-thirds unit. Above the number line, there are labels every four-thirds unit. There is a dot at twenty-thirds, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##What completes $\dfrac43\times5= \square\times\dfrac13$ ?  Now, we need to find the missing information for the equivalent expression $\square\times\dfrac13$.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} {\redE{\dfrac4{3}}}\times5\\\\ &=5\times\dfrac{\redE4\times\redE1}{3}\\\\ &=5\times\redE4\times\dfrac{\redE1}{3}\\\\ &=\redE{20}\times\dfrac13 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:  [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac43\times5$ and $20\times\dfrac{1}{3}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 5 equal parts with each part labeled four-thirds. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 20 equal parts with each part labeled one-third. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-thirds to twenty-thirds with tick marks at every one-third unit and labels every five-thirds unit. Above the number line, there are labels every four-thirds unit. There is a dot at twenty-thirds, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: Here is the complete table:   | | :- | :- | $\dfrac43\times5$ | $= $ | $\redE{20}\times\dfrac{1}{3}$ $\dfrac43\times5$ | $ = $ | $10\times\dfrac23$ $\dfrac43\times5$| $=$ |  $\dfrac{10}{3}\times2$

question.content: Emily is making a table with expressions that are equal to $\dfrac32\times2$.  **Help Emily complete the table.**   | | :- | :- | $\dfrac32\times2$ | $= $ | $\dfrac{2}{2}\times3$ $\dfrac32\times2$ | $ = $ | $6\times{}$   $\dfrac32\times2$| $=$ |  $1\times\dfrac62$

hints.content: Emily was able to find several equivalent expressions to $\dfrac32\times2$.   Let's see how she did it!

##Why does $\dfrac32\times2=\dfrac{2}{2}\times3$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{\dfrac32}\times2\\\\ &=\left(\dfrac{\blueD3\times\blueD1}{\blueD2}\right) \times 2\\\\ &=\blueD3\times \left(\dfrac{\blueD1\times2}{2} \right)\\\\ &=\blueD3\times\dfrac22\\\\ &=\dfrac22\times3 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac32\times2$ and $3\times\dfrac{2}{2}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 2 equal parts with each part labeled three-halves. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 3 equal parts with each part labeled two-halves. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-halves to six-halves with tick marks at every one-half unit and labels every two-halves unit. Above the number line, there are labels every three-halves unit. There is a dot at six-halves, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##Why does $\dfrac32\times2=1\times\dfrac62$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} {\maroonD{\dfrac3{2}}}\times2\\\\ &=\dfrac{\maroonD1\times\maroonD3}{2}\times2\\\\ &=\maroonD1\times \left(\dfrac{\maroonD3\times2}{2} \right)\\\\ &=1\times\dfrac62 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:    [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac32\times2$ and $1\times\dfrac62$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 2 equal parts with each part labeled three-halves. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is labeled six-halves. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-halves to six-halves with tick marks at every one-half unit and labels every six-halves unit. Above the number line, there are labels every three-halves unit. There is a dot at six-halves, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##What completes $\dfrac32\times2= \square\times\dfrac1{2}$ ?  Now, we need to find the missing information for the equivalent expression $\square\times\dfrac1{2}$.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} {\goldD{\dfrac3{2}}}\times2\\\\ &=\dfrac{\goldD1\times\goldD3}{2}\times2\\\\ &=\goldD{\dfrac1{2}}\times(3\times2)\\\\ &=\goldD{\dfrac1{2}}\times6 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac{3}{2}\times2$ and $\dfrac{1}{2}\times6$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 2 equal parts with each part labeled three-halves. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 6 equal parts with each part labeled one-half. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-halves to six-halves with tick marks at every one-half unit. Above the number line, there are labels every three-halves unit. There is a dot at six-halves, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: Here is the complete table:   | | :- | :- | $\dfrac32\times2$ | $= $ | $\dfrac{2}{2}\times3$ $\dfrac32\times2$ | $ = $ | $6\times{}\goldD{\dfrac12}$ $\dfrac32\times2$| $=$ |  $1\times\dfrac62$

question.content: Jackson is making a table with expressions that are equal to $\dfrac9{10}\times3$.  **Help Jackson complete the table.**   | | :- | :- | $\dfrac9{10}\times3$ | $= $ | $27\times{}$  $\dfrac9{10}\times3$ | $ = $ | $9\times\dfrac3{10}$ $\dfrac9{10}\times3$| $=$ |  $\dfrac{27}{10}\times1$

hints.content: Jackson was able to find several equivalent expressions to $\dfrac9{10}\times3$.   Let's see how he did it!

##Why does $\dfrac9{10}\times3=9\times\dfrac3{10}$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{\dfrac9{10}}\times3\\\\ &=\left(\dfrac{\blueD3\times\blueD3}{\blueD{10}} \right) \times3\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac3{10}}\times(3\times3)\\\\ &=\dfrac3{10}\times9\\\\ &=9\times\dfrac3{10} \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:  [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac9{10}\times3$ and $9\times\dfrac3{10}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 3 equal parts with each part labeled nine-tenths. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 9 equal parts with each part labeled three-tenths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-tenths to twenty-seven tenths with tick marks at every one-tenth unit and labels every three-tenths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every nine-tenths unit. There is a dot at twenty-seven tenths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##Why does $\dfrac9{10}\times3=\dfrac{27}{10}\times1$ ?  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} {\maroonD{\dfrac4{3}}}\times5\\\\ &=\dfrac{\maroonD2\times\maroonD2}{3}\times5\\\\ &=\maroonD2\times \left( \dfrac{\maroonD2\times5}{3} \right)\\\\ &=2\times\dfrac{10}3\\\\ &=\dfrac{10}{3}\times2 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac9{10}\times3$ and $\dfrac{27}{10}\times1$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 3 equal parts with each part labeled nine-tenths. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is labeled twenty-seven tenths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-tenths to twenty-seven tenths with tick marks at every one-tenth unit and labels every twenty-seven tenths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every nine-tenths unit. There is a dot at twenty-seven tenths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: ##What completes $\dfrac9{10}\times3= 27\times\square$ ?  Now, we need to find the missing information for the equivalent expression $27\times\square$.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \dfrac9{10}\times3\\\\ &=\dfrac{\redE1\times\redE9}{10}\times3\\\\ &=\dfrac1{10}\times(\redE9\times3)\\\\ &=\dfrac1{10}\times\redE{27} \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:  [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac9{10}\times3$ and $27\times\dfrac{1}{10}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 3 equal parts. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 27 equal parts. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-tenths to twenty-seven tenths with tick marks and labels at every one-tenth unit. Above the number line, there are labels every nine-tenths unit. There is a dot at twenty-seven tenths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: Here is the complete table:   | | :- | :- | $\dfrac9{10}\times3$ | $= $ | $27\times\redE{\dfrac1{10}}$ $\dfrac9{10}\times3$ | $ = $ | $9\times\dfrac3{10}$ $\dfrac9{10}\times3$| $=$ |  $\dfrac{27}{10}\times1$

question.content: **Complete the equations.**   |  |  -: | - | :-  ${4} \times \dfrac{{3}}{{10}}$ | $=$ | ${4}\times{}$ ${}\times\dfrac{1}{{10}}$  ${4} \times \dfrac{{3}}{{10}}$| $=$|  ${}\times\dfrac{1}{10}$

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $4\times\dfrac3{10}$ to find the equivalent expression.  Remember, we can break apart $\dfrac{3}{10}$ into a unit fraction and rearrange the numbers to make equivalent expressions.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 4 \times \blueE{\dfrac{3}{10}}\\\\ &=4 \times \left(\blueE{3\times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=(4 \times \blueE3) \blueE{\times \dfrac{1}{10}}\\\\ &= 12 \times \dfrac{1}{10} \end{align}$
We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $4\times\dfrac{3}{10}$ and $12 \times \dfrac{1}{10}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 4 equal parts with each part labeled three-tenths. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 12 equal parts with each part labeled one-tenth. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-tenths to twelve-tenths with tick marks at every one-tenth unit. Above the number line, there are labels every three-tenths unit. There is a dot at twelve-tenths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: These are the complete equations:   $\begin{align} 4 \times \dfrac{3}{10} &= 4 \times \boxed{3} \times \dfrac{1}{10}\\\\ {4} \times \dfrac{{3}}{{10}} &= \boxed{12} \times \dfrac{1}{10} \end{align}$

question.content: **Complete the equations.**   |  |  -: | - | :-  $7 \times \dfrac{5}{12}$ | $=$ | ${7}\times{}$ ${}\times\dfrac{1}{{12}}$  $7 \times \dfrac{5}{12}$| $=$|  ${}\times\dfrac{1}{12}$

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $7\times\dfrac5{12}$ to find the equivalent expression.  Remember, we can break apart $\dfrac{5}{12}$ into a unit fraction and rearrange the numbers to make equivalent expressions.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 7 \times \blueE{\dfrac{5}{12}}\\\\ &=7 \times\left(\blueE{5\times \dfrac{1}{12}}\right)\\\\ &=(7 \times \blueE5)\blueE{\times \dfrac{1}{12}}\\\\ &= 35 \times \dfrac{1}{12} \end{align}$
We can also visualize the expressions:  [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $7\times\dfrac{5}{12}$ and $35\times \dfrac{1}{12}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 7 equal parts. The bottom bar is divided into 35 parts. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-twelfths to thirty-five twelfths with tick marks at every one-twelfth unit. Every five-twelfth unit is labeled above and below the number line. There is a green dot at thirty-five twelfths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: These are the complete equations:   $\begin{align} 7\times \dfrac{5}{12} &= 7 \times \boxed{5} \times \dfrac{1}{12}\\\\ 7\times \dfrac{5}{12}&= \boxed{35} \times \dfrac{1}{12} \end{align}$

question.content: **Complete the equations.**   |  |  -: | - | :-  $2 \times \dfrac85$ | $=$ | ${2}\times{}$ ${}\times\dfrac{1}{{5}}$  $2 \times \dfrac85$| $=$|  ${}\times\dfrac{1}{5}$

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $2\times\dfrac8{5}$ to find the equivalent expression.   Remember, we can break apart $\dfrac{8}{5}$ into a unit fraction and rearrange the numbers to make equivalent expressions.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 2\times \blueE{\dfrac{8}{5}}\\\\ &=2 \times \left( \blueE{8 \times \dfrac{1}{5}}\right)\\\\\ &=(2 \times \blueE{8}) { \times \blueE{\dfrac15}}\\\\ &= 16 \times \dfrac{1}{5} \end{align}$
We can also visualize the expressions:    [[☃ image 1]]    The expressions $2\times\dfrac{8}{5}$ and $16\times \dfrac{1}{5}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

hints.content: These are the complete equations:   $\begin{align} 2\times \dfrac{8}{5} &= 2 \times \boxed{8} \times \dfrac{1}{5}\\\\ 2\times \dfrac{8}{5}&= \boxed{16} \times \dfrac{1}{5} \end{align}$

question.content: **Complete the equations.**   |  |  -: | - | :-  $5 \times \dfrac34$ | $=$ | ${5}\times{}$ ${}\times\dfrac{1}{{4}}$  $5 \times \dfrac34$| $=$|  ${}\times\dfrac{1}{4}$

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $5\times\dfrac3{4}$ to find the equivalent expression.   Remember, we can break apart $\dfrac{3}{4}$ into a unit fraction and rearrange the numbers to make equivalent expressions.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 5 \times \blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}\\\\ &=5 \times\left( \blueE{3 \times \dfrac{1}{4}}\right)\\\\ &=(5 \times \blueE{3}) \blueE{\times \dfrac{1}{4}}\\\\ &=15 \times \dfrac{1}{4} \end{align}$
We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]    The expressions $5\times\dfrac{3}{4}$ and $15\times \dfrac{1}{4}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

question.content: **Complete the equations.**   |  |  -: | - | :-  $14 \times \dfrac{1}{6}$ | $=$ | ${2}\times{}$ ${}\times\dfrac{1}{{6}}$  $14 \times \dfrac{1}{6}$| $=$|  ${}\times\dfrac{7}{6}$

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $14\times\dfrac1{6}$ to find the equivalent expression.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \greenD{14} \times \dfrac{1}{6}\\\\ &=(\greenD{2 \times 7})\times \dfrac{1}{6}\\\\ &=\greenD{2} \times \left(\greenD7 \times \dfrac{1}{6}\right)\\\\ &= \greenD{2} \times \dfrac{\greenD7}{6} \end{align}$
We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $14\times\dfrac{1}{6}$ and $2\times \dfrac{7}{6}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 14 equal parts with each part labeled one-sixth. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 2 equal parts with each part labeled seven-sixths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-sixths to fourteen-sixths with tick marks at every one-sixth unit and labels every seven-sixths units. Above the number line, there are labels every one-sixth unit. There is a dot at fourteen-sixths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: These are the complete equations:   $\begin{align} 14 \times \dfrac{1}{6} &= 2\times \boxed{7} \times \dfrac{1}{6}\\\\ 14 \times \dfrac{1}{6} &= \boxed{2} \times \dfrac{7}{6} \end{align}$

question.content: **Complete the equations.**   |  |  -: | - | :-  $12 \times \dfrac{1}{3}$ | $=$ | $6\times{}$  $\times{}\dfrac{1}{{3}}$  $12 \times \dfrac{1}{3}$| $=$|  ${}\times\dfrac{2}{3}$

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $12\times\dfrac1{3}$ to find the equivalent expression.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \greenD{12} \times \dfrac{1}{3}\\\\ &=(\greenD{6} \times 2)\times \dfrac{1}{3}\\\\ &=\greenD{6} \times \left(\greenD2\times \dfrac{1}{3}\right)\\\\ &= \greenD{6 }\times \dfrac{\greenD2}{3} \end{align}$
We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $12\times\dfrac{1}{3}$ and $6\times \dfrac{2}{3}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 12 equal parts with each part labeled one-third. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 6 equal parts with each part labeled two-thirds. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-thirds to twelve-thirds with tick marks at every one-third unit and labels every two-thirds unit. Above the number line, there are labels every one-third unit. There is a dot at twelve-thirds, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: These are the complete equations:   $\begin{align} 12\times\dfrac{1}{3}&= 6\times \boxed{2} \times \dfrac{1}{3}\\\\ 12\times\dfrac{1}{3}&= \boxed{6} \times \dfrac{2}{3} \end{align}$

question.content: **Complete the equations.**   |  |  -: | - | :-  $20 \times \dfrac14$ | $=$ | $5\times{}$  $\times{}\dfrac{1}{{4}}$  $20 \times \dfrac14$| $=$|  ${}\times\dfrac{4}{4}$

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $20\times\dfrac1{4}$ to find the equivalent expression.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \greenD{20} \times \dfrac{1}{4}\\\\ &=(\greenD{5} \times 4)\times \dfrac{1}{4}\\\\ &=\greenD{5} \times \left(\greenD4\times \dfrac{1}{4}\right)\\\\ &= \greenD{5} \times \greenD{\dfrac{4}{4}} \end{align}$
We can also visualize the expressions:    [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $20\times\dfrac{1}{4}$ and $5\times \dfrac{4}{4}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 20 equal parts with each part labeled one-fourth. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 5 equal parts with each part labeled four-fourths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-fourths to twenty-fourths with tick marks at every one-fourth unit and labels every four-fourths. Above the number line, there are labels every two-fourths unit. There is a dot at twenty-fourths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: These are the complete equations:   $\begin{align} 20\times\dfrac{1}{4}&= 5\times \boxed{4} \times \dfrac{1}{4}\\\\ 20\times\dfrac{1}{4}&= \boxed{5} \times \dfrac{4}{4} \end{align}$

question.content: **Select two expressions that are equivalent to $4 \times \dfrac{3}{10}$.**

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $4\times\dfrac3{10}$ to find other equivalent expressions.  Remember, we can break apart $\dfrac{3}{10}$ into a unit fraction and rearrange the numbers to make equivalent expressions.

$\begin{align} 4 \times \blueD{\dfrac{3}{10}} &=4 \times \left(\blueD{3\times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=(4 \times \blueD3) \blueD{\times \dfrac{1}{10}}\\\\ &= 12 \times \dfrac{1}{10} \end{align}$   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $4\times\dfrac{3}{10}$ and $12 \times \dfrac{1}{10}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 4 equal parts with each part labeled three-tenths. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 12 equal parts with each part labeled one-tenth. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-tenths to twelve-tenths with tick marks at every one-tenth unit. Above the number line, there are labels every three-tenths unit. There is a dot at twelve-tenths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \greenD4 \times {\dfrac{3}{10}} &= (\greenD2\times\greenD2) \times \dfrac{3}{10}\\\\ &=\greenD2\times \left(\greenD2 \times\dfrac{3}{10}\right)\\\\ &= 2 \times \dfrac{6}{10}\\\\ &=\dfrac{6}{10}\times2 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $4\times\dfrac{3}{10}$ and $2 \times \dfrac{6}{10}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 4 equal parts with each part labeled three-tenths. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 2 equal parts with each part labeled six-tenths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-tenths to twelve-tenths with tick marks at every one-tenth unit and labels every six-tenths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every three-tenths unit. There is a dot at twelve-tenths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: The following expressions are equivalent to $4 \times \dfrac{3}{10}$:  * $\dfrac6{10}\times 2$  * $3\times\dfrac{4}{10}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]

question.content: **Select two expressions that are equivalent to $3 \times \dfrac{7}{4}$.**

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $3\times\dfrac74$ to find other equivalent expressions.   Remember, we can break apart $\dfrac{7}{4}$ into a unit fraction and rearrange the numbers to make equivalent expressions.

$\begin{align} 3 \times \blueD{\dfrac{7}{4}} &=3 \times \left(\blueD{7\times \dfrac{1}{4}}\right)\\\\ &=(3 \times \blueD7) \blueD{\times \dfrac{1}{4}}\\\\ &= 21 \times \dfrac{1}{4} \end{align}$  [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $3\times\dfrac{7}{4}$ and $21 \times \dfrac{1}{4}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-fourths to twenty-one fourths with tick marks at every one-fourth unit. Above the number line, there are labels every seven-fourths unit. There is a dot at twenty-one fourths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

question.content: **Select two expressions that are equivalent to $2 \times \dfrac{10}{3}$. **

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $2\times\dfrac{10}3$ to find other equivalent expressions.   Remember, we can break apart $\dfrac{10}{3}$ into a unit fraction and rearrange the numbers to make equivalent expressions.

$\begin{align} 2 \times \blueD{\dfrac{10}{3}} &=2 \times \left(\blueD{10\times \dfrac{1}{3}}\right)\\\\ &=(2 \times \blueD{10}) \blueD{\times \dfrac{1}{3}}\\\\ &= 20 \times \dfrac{1}{3} \end{align}$   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $2\times\dfrac{10}{3}$ and $20 \times \dfrac{1}{3}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

hints.content: $\begin{align} 2\times {\greenD{\dfrac{10}{3}}} &= 2\times \dfrac{\greenD2\times\greenD5}{3}\\\\ &=(2\times \greenD2) \times\dfrac{\greenD5}{3}\\\\ &= 4 \times \dfrac{5}{3}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{3}\times4 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $2\times\dfrac{10}{3}$ and $\dfrac{5}{3}\times4$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

question.content: **Select two expressions that are equivalent to $\dfrac32 \times 4$.**

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $\dfrac32\times4$ to find other equivalent expressions.   Remember, we can break apart $\dfrac{3}{2}$ into a unit fraction and rearrange the numbers to make equivalent expressions.

$\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac{3}{2}}\times4 &=\left(\blueD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\times\blueD3\right)\times4\\\\ &=\dfrac12\times(\blueD3 \times4)\\\\ &= \dfrac{1}{2}\times12\\\\ &=12\times\dfrac12 \end{align}$   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac{3}{2}\times4$ and $\dfrac12 \times 12$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 4 equal parts, each labeled three-halves. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 12 equal parts with each part labeled one-half. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-halves to twelve-halves with tick marks at every one-half unit. Above the number line, there are labels every three-halves unit. There is a dot at twelve-halves, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \dfrac32\times \greenD4&= \dfrac32 \times (\greenD2\times\greenD2)\\\\ &=\left(\dfrac32\times \greenD2\right) \times\greenD2\\\\ &= \dfrac{6}{2}\times2 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:    [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac{3}{2}\times4$ and $\dfrac{6}{2}\times2$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 4 equal parts, each labeled three-halves. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 2 equal parts with each part labeled six-halves. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-halves to twelve-halves with labeled tick marks at every six-halves unit. Above the number line, there are labels every three-halves unit. There is a dot at twelve-halves, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: The following expressions are equivalent to $\dfrac{3}{2}\times4$:  * $12\times\dfrac12$  * $\dfrac{6}{2}\times2$  [[☃ explanation 1]]

question.content: **Select two expressions that are equivalent to $\dfrac3{10}\times8$.**

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $\dfrac3{10}\times8$ to find other equivalent expressions.   Remember, we can break apart $\dfrac{3}{10}$ into a unit fraction and rearrange the numbers to make equivalent expressions.

$\begin{align} {\dfrac{3}{10}}\times\blueD8 &={\dfrac{3}{10}}\times(\blueD4\times\blueD2)\\\\ &=(\dfrac1{10}\times3)\times(\blueD4 \times\blueD2)\\\\ &= (\blueD4\times3)\times (\dfrac{1}{10}\times\blueD2)\\\\ &=12\times\dfrac2{10} \end{align}$    [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac{3}{10}\times8$ and $12\dfrac2{10}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 8 equal parts, each labeled three-tenths. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 12 equal parts with each part labeled two-tenths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-tenths to twenty-four tenths with labeled tick marks at every two-tenths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every three-tenths unit. There is a dot at twenty-four tenths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \dfrac3{10}\times \greenD8&=\left(\greenD{\dfrac1{10}\times 3}\right)\times 8\\\\ &=\greenD{\dfrac1{10}}\times(\greenD3\times8)\\\\ &= \dfrac{1}{10}\times24 \end{align}$  We can also visualize the expressions:  [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac{3}{10}\times8$ and $\dfrac{1}{10}\times24$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 8 equal parts. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 24 equal parts. There is a dot at twenty-four tenths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

question.content: **Select two expressions that are equivalent to $\dfrac1{3}\times4$.**

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $\dfrac1{3}\times4$ to find other equivalent expressions.

$\begin{align} {\dfrac{1}{3}}\times\blueD4 &={\dfrac{1}{3}}\times(\blueD2\times\blueD2)\\\\ &=(\dfrac1{3}\times\blueD2)\times\blueD2\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD2}{3} \times \blueD2\\\\ &=2\times\dfrac23 \end{align}$   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $\dfrac{1}{3}\times4$ and $2\times\dfrac23$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 2 equal parts with each part labeled two-thirds. There is a dot at four-thirds, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of equal lengths. The top bar is divided into 4 equal parts, each labeled one-third. The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is  labeled four-thirds. question.content: **Select two expressions that are equivalent to $\dfrac15 \times 24$.**

hints.content: Let's see how we can rearrange the expression $\dfrac15 \times 24$ to find other equivalent expressions.

$\begin{align} {\blueD{24}\times\dfrac{1}{5}}&=(\blueD6\times\blueD4)\times\dfrac15\\\\ &=\blueD6\times(\blueD4\times\dfrac15)\\\\ &= \blueD6\times\dfrac{\blueD4}5 \end{align}$  [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $24\times\dfrac{1}{5}$ and $6\times\dfrac45$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 6 equal parts with each part labeled four-fifths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-fifths to twenty-four fifths with labeled tick marks at every four-fifths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every two-fifths unit. There is a dot at twenty-four fifths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \greenD{24}\times\dfrac15&=(\greenD8\times\greenD3)\times\dfrac15\\\\ &=\greenD8\times \left(\greenD3\times\dfrac15\right)\\\\ &=\greenD8\times\dfrac{\greenD3}5 \end{align}$   [[☃ image 1]]  The expressions $24\times\dfrac{1}{5}$ and $\dfrac35\times8$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.
